reviewText:
7/10 A good game with several severe drawbacks to itReview for the Street Fighter X Tekken: Complete Pack version 1.08

Both the Street Fighter & the Tekken franchise are video game milestones. Capcomâ€™s Street Fighter II (1991) became famous for introducing mechanics we nowadays perceive as normal, such as combos, cancellations, or lenient controls. Bandai-Namcoâ€™s Tekken series (1994 ongoing) then built upon this & Segaâ€™s Virtua Fighterâ€™s legacy (1993 ongoing) to sweep the market with 3D fighting arenas, new control schemes, more realistic fighting moves, & beginner friendly controls that displayed a remarkable, never before seen depth to them. It seems like a no-brainer for these two giants to meet up in this crossover from 2012. But whether this 2.5D mashup fared well or not, is a completely different question.

About the game Mechanics
Movesets
The mechanics & controls of both  Tekken & Street Fighter could not be any further apart with one being build around 3D arenas while the other was made with 2D environments in mind. SFxT tries to solve this problem by greeting players with a surprisingly deep fighting mechanic that has multiple means of individualizing the charactersâ€™ movesets. Nevertheless, using Tekken characters does feel alien.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=685384490
Generally, the game shares several of the mechanics of the Street Fighter IV franchise (2008-2014), but adds optional, simplified special attacks (e.g. instead of â†“â†˜â†’â“… just pressing â†˜â“…), customizable button combinations, & quick combos to make it easier for Tekken players & newcomers to find their way into the game. Simplified moves worked well in Tatsunoko vs. Capcom (2008) & sure enough do their job here.

Tag Team
The tag team system is inspired by the Tekken Tag Tournament series (2000 ongoing) with tagouts either being performed through quick combos or by pressing medium kick & medium punch at the same time. The initial problem of the game was that the amount of damage dealt was too low & because each team possesses two healthbars, fights often ended in timeouts instead of KOs. After several patches, this was remedied, but fights can still be unnecessarily drawn out. On the upside, tag teams can even be created in online ranked matches and up to four players can duke it out at once.

Scramble
The scramble mode is obviously the highlight of the on-/offline multiplayer experience, four players can play simultaneously in teams of two. The rounds are quick and chaotic, which just adds more to the fun.

Gems
To further balance the game, SFxT has a gem mechanic. Each character can carry up to three gems at the same time, each having different effects & prerequisites to activate them. Although the gem system makes sense in theory, in practice it is a mess. The amount of available gems is way too large leading to a multitude of confusing combinations that discourage users from looking into this mechanic altogether. Even worse, a large amount of premium gems are only available as purchasable DLC, thus missing the point of being there to level the virtual battle field.

Pandora
In theory Pandora is a great mechanic; sadly itâ€™s not so much in practice. Players sacrifice one party member to temporarily boost the remaining protagonist's powers for a brief amount of time. Once Pandora runs out, the player automatically loses. Therefore it is key to knock the other party out swiftly; unfortunately, because of the gameâ€™s design, Pandora rarely helps win any rounds but instead causes players to lose. So, itâ€™s hardly ever used.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=685384665
Customization
To individualize characters beyond the gems & customized button combinations, players can color their charactersâ€™ clothes. The feature even allows players to either wrap the characters in latex or neon glowing schemes (To see an example of a neon character, click here). Additionally, all base game characters have DLC outfits that are inspired by characters from both franchises.

Backlash
The game had several issues when it first came out. Shaking life bars irritated players & low damage dragged matches out. But it was the DLC policy that ruined the game for many.

Controversy
Although the SFIV series was known for its on-disc DLC, Capcom came under scrutiny upon SFxTâ€™s initial release when it became public that several of the announced twelve DLC characters were already included on the gameâ€™s disc - locked behind a paywall that cost as much as many video games ($19.99 USD). More than that, the Playstation 3 & Vita releases of the game had five additional DLC characters, namely Toro Inoue, Kuro, Cole Mac Grath, Pac-Man, and Bad Box Art Mega Man, while the PC & Xbox360 releases did not receive any exclusives. Further, the Xbox 360 version received even more criticism as the online tag team bouts mentioned in the game's manual did not find their way into that version & were not patched in later on. The big disappointments over the game lead players to stay away from it altogether. After initial attempts, Capcom then decided to stop promoting the game.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=688920867
Games for Windows Live
For the longest time, Capcom refused to transfer both Street Fighter X Tekken &  Resident Evil 5 over from Games for Windows Live to Steam Works. And while RE 5 received this treatment in 2015, SFxT still uses GfWL. Windows 10 users wonâ€™t have any problems logging in, but others will have to jump through hoops to get the game working in the first place. However, once thatâ€™s done, the game & other GfWL services will work just fine.

Online
Sadly, due to its age, negative reputation, less popular design choices, & GfWL, the online population is considerably small & encountering cheaters who use lag switches or rage quit before they lose a match is not uncommon. The remaining players who donâ€™t cheat are often times veterans who far outlevel any newcomers making it increasingly difficult for newcomers to win any matches at all.
Optimization
There's not a lot to say about the game's graphic and control options. It's just as marvelous as with the SFIV series with different AA features, V-Sync, & completely customizable button configurations.
ConclusionDespite it all, SFxT is a good game that suffered from questionable management choices which tarnished the gameâ€™s reception & subsequently was part of what discolored the companyâ€™s reputation for years to come. The arcade stories are fun and the animations have the right level of goofiness to stay refreshing. The PC port is marvelously optimized with tons of graphics options that even allow it to run on toasters". It's definitely worth picking up for a fair price & is truly something that fans would want to check out.

I myself have played pretty much every Street Fighter game that is available out there, including the very first Street Fighter game. And I believe my first Playstation game was Tekken 1. I have loved fighting games since I was a little kid, and I in fact, wanted to get this game, but because of some negative reviews on this game by some people, I decided to just stay away from it for a while. Now that it was on a Steam sale, I have decided to buy it, and well, I am not really sure why people would give bad ratings to this game....sure, you can't really use the Tekken characters like you normally would in the original Tekken games, as the one that made this game is Capcom, but those Tekken characters still maintain their own character even in this game. It kind of sucks that Jin is kind of hard to use in this....or I should say, he either sucks or is for the real hardcore players....or possibly, I simply don't understand how he works in this game yet. But Jin kind of does not really feel like the Jin in the Tekken series. It sucks even more because you can't use Devil Jin, either.

But yes, other than that, I think this is pretty a decent fighting game. I like how so easy it is to do combos and it just feels so good when you successfully execute chain combos using two of your characters. I in fact loved Tekken Tag Tournament 2, which I thought it was the best Tekken game yet, and personally, I would like to say Street Fighter x Tekken is simply the best fighting game I have ever played. Perhaps I am exaggerating, but the fact remains. The game is just damn good. You can also mod the costumes, which are available on the internet or you can simply make your own by using a certain program, so the replay value is there. All I can say is that the game is rather underrated in my opinion. The game is definitely not as bad as people say it is.

Well, it might be because I am a fan of Street Fighter and Tekken series, but I don't know. I believe if you are a fighting game fan, you'd love it in my opinion.

9.9 out of 10

reviewText:
Street Fighter x Tekken is the best Street Fighter game ever, (have not played Street Fighter V yet) There are some pros and con of this game. here is the list.



PROS

1. 38 characters (+12 DLC characters sold seperatly)

2.Great graphics

3.returning characters (Ryu,Ken,Chun-Li,Guile,Etc.) and new characters (Juri, Poison, Hugo (Andore in final fight,)
Guy,Cody,Abel,Rolento)

4.Lots of game modes (versus,arcade,character costumize,training,challenge, combo costumize)

5.All new gem mode, a new roulette like ability that gives your character extra power in a game (speed,strength,etc.)

6.You can fight with a bear.

7.Ability to change the colors of all of the fighters (extra colors sold seperately, but buying a character swap for .99 gets you all colors for free)

8. If you download the game but also have Ultra Street Fighter IV, you will get a free costume for every new character in Ultra Street Fighter Iv that have not appeared in another version of the  Street Fighter IV game (Hugo,Poison,Elena,Decapre,Rolento)




Cons

1.Not enough character colors and costumes (starts with original costume for each character, but have to buy new character costumes individually for .99 each)

2. Can't use Pac-Man or Megaman (PS3 version only)

3. If you don't have a Windows Live account, your data will erase when you close the game and will make you redownload all character costume and color swaps again (if you have any) and you have to reset the character language setting (English or Japanese)

4. Have to buy characters like Sakura, Blanka, Guy, Cody, Dudley, and Elena and 6 Tekken characters I can't remember the names of for $20.00

5. Too much DLC


This game is great. 9.5/10 definitly recommend.

reviewText:
This is my personal honest review about Street fighter X tekken: When i first started Street Fighter X Tekken for the first time I had never owned a Street Fighter or Tekken game so i thought what better way to get to know both game then to play a game that features both fighters. As i went to train i was greeted by a roster of 30+ characters much to my satisfaction as this was a good way to get a grasp on both series's fighters. First i played the Street Fighter side(Chun Li, Cammy,Ryu,Ken,Guy,Dudley Etc.) Then i played the Tekken Side(Law,Asuka,Heihachi,Raven,Nina, Etc.) after playing both sides and scouting what they can do i naturally gravitated to the Tekken side. their characters seem more interesting to me as well as Tekken fits my playstyle: doing long combos and heavy damage is more of my style then tapping people's foot A.K.A Footsieing as one can expect in Street Fighter(Not that Street Fighter is a bad game it just doesn't fit my style) one of my first tekken characters was Law in which i still play as well as Asuka these two characters appealed to me the most. Law's tricky mix ups and Asuka high damage output made them stick out even more to me which none of the Street Fighters could accomplish. But that's enough of my rambling now i will explain what i like and dislike about Street Fighter X Tekken

Pros:

1. Large Character roster: with over 30+ characters there's someone for everyone, for every playstyle.

2. Great english voice acting: All of the Voice Actors in this game sound at the top of their game(No pun intended) none of them sounded bored or tired(Super Street Fighter 4 I'm looking at you)

3. Strategic Gem system: I've heard a lot of mixed reviews about the new gem system and i was one of the ones who didn't like it at first because i though it would dramatically imbalance the game. Luckily i was wrong if you buy the full gem pack you will be greeted to a vast array of game diamonds A.K.A Gems". Gems are stat boosting items that are color-coded in accordance to the stat they boost(Red boosts Attack
date:
Yellow boosts Defense and Green boosts Speed) there are other types of gems such as assist gems the type i was just explaining is called "Boost Gems" which like it states it "Boosts".The gem system gives a tiny strategic boost to the game which i feel is underappreciated.

Cons:

1. Lack of playerbase: (As of now) i assume it's due to the GFWL service shutting down in July but one would assume if a game's online service is shutting down people would play it until the end(Or at least that's just me) It's rather unfortunate as i feel Street Fighter X Tekken is a great game with untapped potential 2 years is way too soon for a game to "Die out" at least that's how i feel.

2. Lack of different modes: In the PC version there are only Arcade
recommended:
Versus and the "Live" mode which enables online play. seeing as the Ps3 and vita versions have Burst Kumite: a mode in which you can fight Computer opponents forever i was shocked to see it wasn't in this version(Probably from sheer laziness on Capcom's part)

3. Online Lag: This is a problem which most fighting games have: bad netcode while not nearly as bad as MK9's netcode(Worst i've ever experienced) it still leaves a lot to be desired. As i look for opponents by the A and B computer rank
(To avoid sloppy connections) I was sad to see players with laggy connections(Some of which went down three bars before the fight would even start) There have been many times in where i start a match with a online player whose connection seemed good at first but became horribly slow making them look like they are teleporting in front of me which i can't even counter. I don't know why this happens but it need to be fixed(Which i doubt it will at least now)

4. Bad matchmaking system: There have been far too many incidents of meeting the same player as i try to search for different players to fight. I fight a person great the fight's over i search for others find that same person over and over and over again to the point where i quit for a while in the hopes of having different competiton by the next time i play("But it's because online is dead for Street Fighter X Tekken PC version") while that may be true I've experienced the same thing on the Vita and Ps3 version despite there being lots of people online at the time. Often when i go online no matter the version i would feel like one of the only online players as i kept running into the same people constantly if only it had a filter button to filter out certain people i don't want to fight again it would help a lot with this problem.


While the bad may outweigh the good I still think Street Fighter X Tekken is a great game gone too soon(Migrating it to steamworks and releasing patches that will buff the netcode might help revive it but i doubt that will happen) you can buy it if you like playing offline but don't even think about going online trust me(At least the PC version). I don't know if i should recommend this game or not but i will if only for the offline content(DLC ahoy!)."

reviewText:
This is my personal honest review about Street fighter X tekken: When i first started Street Fighter X Tekken for the first time I had never owned a Street Fighter or Tekken game so i thought what better way to get to know both game then to play a game that features both fighters. As i went to train i was greeted by a roster of 30+ characters much to my satisfaction as this was a good way to get a grasp on both series's fighters. First i played the Street Fighter side(Chun Li, Cammy,Ryu,Ken,Guy,Dudley Etc.) Then i played the Tekken Side(Law,Asuka,Heihachi,Raven,Nina, Etc.) after playing both sides and scouting what they can do i naturally gravitated to the Tekken side. their characters seem more interesting to me as well as Tekken fits my playstyle: doing long combos and heavy damage is more of my style then tapping people's foot A.K.A Footsieing as one can expect in Street Fighter(Not that Street Fighter is a bad game it just doesn't fit my style) one of my first tekken characters was Law in which i still play as well as Asuka these two characters appealed to me the most. Law's tricky mix ups and Asuka high damage output made them stick out even more to me which none of the Street Fighters could accomplish. But that's enough of my rambling now i will explain what i like and dislike about Street Fighter X Tekken

Pros:

1. Large Character roster: with over 30+ characters there's someone for everyone, for every playstyle.

2. Great english voice acting: All of the Voice Actors in this game sound at the top of their game(No pun intended) none of them sounded bored or tired(Super Street Fighter 4 I'm looking at you)

3. Strategic Gem system: I've heard a lot of mixed reviews about the new gem system and i was one of the ones who didn't like it at first because i though it would dramatically imbalance the game. Luckily i was wrong if you buy the full gem pack you will be greeted to a vast array of game diamonds A.K.A Gems". Gems are stat boosting items that are color-coded in accordance to the stat they boost(Red boosts Attack
date:
Yellow boosts Defense and Green boosts Speed) there are other types of gems such as assist gems the type i was just explaining is called "Boost Gems" which like it states it "Boosts".The gem system gives a tiny strategic boost to the game which i feel is underappreciated.

Cons:

1. Lack of playerbase: (As of now) i assume it's due to the GFWL service shutting down in July but one would assume if a game's online service is shutting down people would play it until the end(Or at least that's just me) It's rather unfortunate as i feel Street Fighter X Tekken is a great game with untapped potential 2 years is way too soon for a game to "Die out" at least that's how i feel.

2. Lack of different modes: In the PC version there are only Arcade
recommended:
Versus and the "Live" mode which enables online play. seeing as the Ps3 and vita versions have Burst Kumite: a mode in which you can fight Computer opponents forever i was shocked to see it wasn't in this version(Probably from sheer laziness on Capcom's part)

3. Online Lag: This is a problem which most fighting games have: bad netcode while not nearly as bad as MK9's netcode(Worst i've ever experienced) it still leaves a lot to be desired. As i look for opponents by the A and B computer rank
(To avoid sloppy connections) I was sad to see players with laggy connections(Some of which went down three bars before the fight would even start) There have been many times in where i start a match with a online player whose connection seemed good at first but became horribly slow making them look like they are teleporting in front of me which i can't even counter. I don't know why this happens but it need to be fixed(Which i doubt it will at least now)

4. Bad matchmaking system: There have been far too many incidents of meeting the same player as i try to search for different players to fight. I fight a person great the fight's over i search for others find that same person over and over and over again to the point where i quit for a while in the hopes of having different competiton by the next time i play("But it's because online is dead for Street Fighter X Tekken PC version") while that may be true I've experienced the same thing on the Vita and Ps3 version despite there being lots of people online at the time. Often when i go online no matter the version i would feel like one of the only online players as i kept running into the same people constantly if only it had a filter button to filter out certain people i don't want to fight again it would help a lot with this problem.


While the bad may outweigh the good I still think Street Fighter X Tekken is a great game gone too soon(Migrating it to steamworks and releasing patches that will buff the netcode might help revive it but i doubt that will happen) you can buy it if you like playing offline but don't even think about going online trust me(At least the PC version). I don't know if i should recommend this game or not but i will if only for the offline content(DLC ahoy!)."

reviewText:
Let's talk about the controversy around SFxT. The on-disc DLC. Dear oh dear, Capcom. There are a few problems with on-disc DLC, but there are also a fair share of problems with the arguments against it. We all know in what ways it's bad, so I won't get into that, instead I will debunk a few of the arguments against it, or rather, explain why it isn't as bad as one might think. Don't get me wrong, there's a huge moral dilemma here, but I am approaching this from an objective stand point.
In any game that has DLC characters and an online mode, there are only two ways to go about this. Either cut off the people with the DLC from the rest of the community, or force a download or install of the DLC for everyone playing online. If the games is to be compatible with other players online, you need to have the data of the DLC characters he has purchased to be able to fight against him. You simply can't load a model you do not have. You also need the data for the characters move-set to be able to be compatible. What SFxT did was to package this data with the disc. This included models and move-set data and in-fight audio, but not cinnematics. If it would not have been on the disc, you wold have had to install a day one patch with the content.
This brings us to my second point; this happens with literally every game with DLC on steam. When you install the game, it installs all available data for the game. All patches and all DLC. Buying the DLC simply unlocks it. This is again for compatibility.
I think these are both valid points to take into consideration when you buy this game. However. There are two counter arguments. 1. Why have day one DLC at all? 2. Is it really OK for a fighting game, which is competetive in nature, to have DLC chatacters? This can throw off the ballance of the game drastically. It was terrible when they did it in UMvC3, and it is still terrible. And look what happened to UMvC3. Capcom lost the marvel liscence, and now you can't buy the DLC anymore. So there are people online with characters you can't get. If someone finds an exploit that favours one of these characters now, that will throw ballance out the window. Thn you've got a character that is impossible to unlock, that is supperior to the other characters.

As for the game itself; it's fun. I like it a lot. It is faster than SSF4AE, and the tagging opens up a lot of possibilities for combos. The one glaring flaw with the game is, of course, the gems. I don't know who at Capcom thought they were a good idea, but that person should be fired. There is no way to turn them off, and it can give advantages to players who bought the gem DLC. It's stupid, it hurts the competitive scene, and I don't like it. I'd say stick to the default set-up of gems.

reviewText: This game is a real blast. I can just pick it up and play until I get bored. The fast fighting mechanics is really fun to master and Street Fighter mixing with Tekken is nostalgic all around. One obviously frustrating issue is Games for Windows Live but that's an entirely different argument although still a very big part of this game. For a while GFWL was down and I couldn't reach my save game. When I found there was an offline account option the issues were over. I like fighting games but I'm not the type to master them like some Korean kid playing SF4 constantly in his local arcade. SS4 was not fun due to the seemingly slower gameplay with more cartoon graphics and a very challenging system to learn before it's even remotely enjoyable. This game is much more accessible to anyone who wishes to casually play a fighter. Graphics are crisp but I'm not in to the comically absurd character design. A bit of smart button smashing can lead to a sweet combo and character switch for an even better combo. I recommend this to any on the fence fighting game gamers.
